channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #228 - Advent Season
item.description: With December comes back a beloved Perl tradition: the Advent calendars. In other seasonal news, Christmas is getting ever closer for Perl 6. And on a slightly more "bah humbug"ish note, the various Perl-related Kickstarters aren't doing so well right now. But hey, this season is known for its miracles, so... we never know. In the meantime, enjoy! ~ `/anick
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: Senior Applications Engineer
item.description: Uniregistry is looking for a talented and passionate engineer to build and maintain a world-class registry and registrar. This position requires the ability to analyze and implement elegant solutions to complex problems while contributing to the development of reusable components

item.title: Supporting the Perl Weekly?
item.description: Would you like to support the Perl Weekly? A Perl Job ad in the Perl Weekly, like the one above, will reach almost 6000 Perl developers. People like you, who are enthusiastic about Perl and not just use it as an ad-on tool.

item.title: Help us sponsor the Dancer book!
item.description: The Dancer book kickstarter has 6 days and 8 thousand euros to do.

item.title: Suspending efforts on my #riba2016 crowdfunding campaign, looking forward to my own Xmas
item.description: An update on Peter's Kickstarter to be able to focus on Open Source/CPAN development for 2016.

item.title: Browserling was product of the day on Product Hunt!
item.description: Peteris's Browserling (a cross-browser testing solution) was featured by ProductHunt.com, a site featuring and ranking different software. Good to know Browersling is doing good; interesting to learn about that ProductHunt site thingie.

item.title: Making the Larry Wall shirt
item.description: David made a cool "Larry Wall, hero of the revolution" t-shirt (if you want one, the Kickstarter is still ongoing, hurry!). He shares here the how he uses Gimp and Inkscape to create the t-shirt's picture.

item.title: The Veure MMORPG Saga Continues
item.description: Ovid teases us with can be described as a tantalizing textual trailer to his upcoming space MMORPG, Veure.

item.title: London Perl Workshop 2015
item.description: The London Perl Workshop is going to happen in a few days, and it looks like it's going to be awesome.

item.title: Getting ready for MongoDB 3.2: new features, new Perl driver beta
item.description: A new release of MongoDB is coming up. And a new trial version of its driver is already accessible on CPAN. MongoDB peeps you know what that means.

item.title: Interactive shells
item.description: Either for abyss-level bug hunting, or interactive toying with the language, REPLs are invaluable. Matt reviews some of the proeminent Perl REPL out there for us.

item.title: Free go faster stripes for your Perl programs
item.description: There is an an optimization coming for Perl 5.24 that might boost some benchmarks by 25% to 40%. Sinan gives the nitty gritty details of this upcoming nitro injection to the Perl engine.

item.title: Say 'Hello' to JSON::Schema::AsType
item.description: A new module that turns JSON schemas into Type::Tiny types.

item.title: November 2015 Grant Votes
item.description: A grant to merge stabilize and merge Test::Stream and Test::Simple into perl-blead has been approved.

item.title: Arrays Shape Up, Curli Lands and Supply Splits
item.description: Quite a lot of stuff happening in Perl6-land this week: a new Rakudo version, a new tutorial, a new Advent calendar, and lots of small stuff falling into place.

item.title: Getting closer to Christmas
item.description: Last time, John was counting 40 tickets standing between us and Christmas. Now the number is down to 20.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Monitoring the most recent uploads to CPAN
item.description: Are you looking for a place to contribute. Here is the 100 most recently uploaded modules that are either missing the link to their repository, have no Travis-CI enabled, or have no license in the META files.
